required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Role of Parents in Adolescent Weight Loss
clinical_study.official_title: Parental Involvement as a Strategy to Enhance Adolescent Weight Control

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to determine whether a novel model of including parents in adolescent weight control results in greater decrease in adolescent z-BMI compared to an intervention with minimal parent involvement.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and at completion of 16 week intervention

secondary_outcome.description: Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Parent modeling of dietary choices was assessed using the Diet Choices subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Dietary choices subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0 - 4, with higher scores corresponding to healthier diet choices. Higher scores are considered to be a better treatment outcome.

Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Parent modeling of self-monitoring behavior was assessed using the Self Monitoring subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Self Monitoring subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0 - 4, with higher scores corresponding to more self-monitoring behavior. Higher scores are thought to reflect a better treatment outcome.

Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Parent modeling of Physical Activity was assessed using the Physical Activity subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Physical Activity subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0-4, with higher scores corresponding to greater physical activity. Higher scores are considered a better treatment outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Parent Modeling 4: Weight and Body Concerns (FERF-Q)
secondary_outcome.description: Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Parent modeling of concern about weight/body was assessed using the Parent Modeling of Weight and Body Concerns subscale of the Family Experiences Related to Food Questionnaire (FERF-Q)), an adolescent-report measure of parent behavior pertaining to weight control. The Weight and Body Concerns subscale of the FERF-Q has a scale range of 1 - 5, with higher scores corresponding to greater parent weight and body concerns, as perceived and reported by the adolescent. Lower weight and body concern is considered a better treatment outcome.

Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Negative maternal weight-related commentary was assessed using the Negative maternal weight-related commentary subscale of the Family Experiences Related to Food Questionnaire (FERF-Q)), an adolescent-report measure of parent behavior pertaining to weight control. The Negative maternal weight-related commentary subscale of the FERF-Q has a scale range of 1 - 5, with higher scores corresponding to greater negative maternal weight-related commentary, as perceived and reported by the adolescent. Lower scores are considered a better treatment outcome.

Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Observed parent-adolescent communication quality was measured using the Dyadic Observed Communication Scale (DOCS) used to code communication between adolescent and caregiver during a video-taped observational coding session. The DOCS is coded on a scale of 0 -10, with higher scores reflecting higher quality of communication, as observed by an independent rater. Higher scores are thought to reflect a better treatment outcome.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Behavioral Weight Control with Enhanced Parent Involvement
arm_group.description: This treatment arm included periodic dyadic sessions with adolescents and their parents, focusing on weight-related communication combined with standard behavioral weight control.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Behavioral Weight Control with Minimal Parent Involvement
arm_group.description: This treatment arm included standard behavioral weight control delivered to the adolescent with minimal parent involvement.

intervention.intervention_name: Behavioral Weight Control with Enhanced Parent Involvement
intervention.arm_group_label: Behavioral Weight Control with Enhanced Parent Involvement

intervention.intervention_name: Behavioral Weight Control with Minimal Parent Involvement
intervention.arm_group_label: Behavioral Weight Control with Minimal Parent Involvement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Between 30 and 90% overweight
- Parent or guardian willing to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Major psychiatric disorder

group.title: Behavioral Weight Control With Minimal Parent Involvement
group.description: This treatment arm included standard behavioral weight control delivered to the adolescent with minimal parent involvement. Behavioral Weight Control with Minimal Parent Involvement

group.title: Behavioral Weight Control With Enhanced Parent Involvement
group.description: This treatment arm included periodic dyadic sessions with adolescents and their parents, focusing on weight-related communication combined with standard behavioral weight control. Behavioral Weight Control with Enhanced Parent Involvement

group.description: This treatment arm included periodic dyadic sessions with adolescents and their parents, focusing on weight-related communication combined with standard behavioral weight control. Behavioral Weight Control with Enhanced Parent Involvement

group.title: Behavioral Weight Control With Minimal Parent Involvement
group.description: This treatment arm included standard behavioral weight control delivered to the adolescent with minimal parent involvement. Behavioral Weight Control with Minimal Parent Involvement

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Parent modeling 1: Dietary Choices (WCSS)
measure.description: Parent modeling of dietary choices was assessed using the Diet Choices subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Dietary choices subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0 - 4, with higher scores corresponding to healthier diet choices.

measure.title: Parent modeling 2: Self-monitoring (WCSS)
measure.description: Parent modeling of self-monitoring behavior was assessed using the Self Monitoring subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Self Monitoring subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0 - 4, with higher scores corresponding to more self-monitoring behavior.

measure.title: Parent modeling 3: Physical Activity (WCSS)
measure.description: ). Parent modeling of Physical Activity was assessed using the Physical Activity subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Physical Activity subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0-4, with higher scores corresponding to greater physical activity.

measure.title: Parent modeling 4: Weight and Body Concerns
measure.description: Parent modeling of concern about weight/body was assessed using the Parent Modeling of Weight and Body Concerns subscale of the Family Experiences Related to Food Questionnaire (FERF-Q)), an adolescent-report measure of parent behavior pertaining to weight control. The Weight and Body Concerns subscale of the FERF-Q has a scale range of 1 - 5, with greater scores corresponding to greater parent weight and body concerns, as perceived and reported by the adolescent.

measure.title: Communication 1: Negative weight-related comments
measure.description: Negative maternal weight-related commentary was assessed using the Negative maternal weight-related commentary subscale of the Family Experiences Related to Food Questionnaire (FERF-Q)), an adolescent-report measure of parent behavior pertaining to weight control. The Negative maternal weight-related commentary subscale of the FERF-Q has a scale range of 1 - 5, with higher scores corresponding to greater negative maternal weight-related commentary, as perceived and reported by the adolescent.

measure.title: Communication 2: Observed parent-adolescent communication quality
measure.description: Observed parent-adolescent communication quality was measured using the Dyadic Observed Communication Scale (DOCS) used to code communication between adolescent and caregiver during a video-taped observational coding session. The DOCS is coded on a scale of 0 -10, with higher scores reflecting higher quality of communication, as observed by an independent rater.

outcome.title: Body Mass Index
outcome.time_frame: Baseline and at completion of 16 week intervention

group.title: Behavioral Weight Control With Minimal Parent Involvement
group.description: This treatment arm included standard behavioral weight control delivered to the adolescent with minimal parent involvement. Behavioral Weight Control with Minimal Parent Involvement

group.title: Behavioral Weight Control With Enhanced Parent Involvement
group.description: This treatment arm included periodic dyadic sessions with adolescents and their parents, focusing on weight-related communication combined with standard behavioral weight control. Behavioral Weight Control with Enhanced Parent Involvement

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis was that the amount of weight lost by adolescents in Enhanced Parent Involvement and Minimal Parent involvement would not be significantly different. The study was powered at .8 to achieve a medium effect size (f = .26; partial eta sq. = 0.06). The end-of-treatment BMI value was the dependent variable, with the baseline BMI value entered as a covariate.

outcome.title: Parent Modeling 1: Dietary Choices (WCSS)
outcome.description: Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Parent modeling of dietary choices was assessed using the Diet Choices subscale of the Weight Control Strategies Scale (WCSS), a parent-report measure of his/her own healthy weight control practices. The Dietary choices subscale of the WCSS has a scale range of 0 - 4, with higher scores corresponding to healthier diet choices. Higher scores are considered to be a better treatment outcome.
outcome.population: Secondary outcomes analyzed for treatment completers only.

outcome.title: Communication 2: Observed Parent-adolescent Communication Quality (DOCS)
outcome.description: Post-treatment value (controlling for baseline). Observed parent-adolescent communication quality was measured using the Dyadic Observed Communication Scale (DOCS) used to code communication between adolescent and caregiver during a video-taped observational coding session. The DOCS is coded on a scale of 0 -10, with higher scores reflecting higher quality of communication, as observed by an independent rater. Higher scores are thought to reflect a better treatment outcome.
outcome.population: 38 participants (19 in each group) had complete baseline and post treatment data for videotaped observations.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
